courseDescription: Student participation in a supervised, undergraduate research experience for which credit will not apply to the degree.  Experience must be related to the student's major, minor or career area of interest.

Introduction to the scientific study of psychology, including the methods used to gather and interpret data.  The student is introduced to fundamental terms, theories, and concepts dealing with the biological bases of behavior; learning; perception; cognition and intelligence; personality; psychological disorders; human development; and social processes.  An emphasis is placed on application of concepts and critical thinking.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of psychological methods and data interpretation
Knowledge of psychological theories and concepts
Understanding of the biological bases of behavior
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Applying psychological theories to social processes
Understanding of personality and psychological disorders

courseDescription: A broad contemporary view of the processes of development.  The influences of biological and environmental factors in the development of personality and cognitive functioning are explored.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of biological influences on development
Knowledge of environmental factors in development
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating the role of environmental and biological factors in development
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the interaction between genetic and environmental influences
Interpreting the effects of different factors on personality development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing complex information on lifespan development
Leading discussions on developmental theories and concepts

courseDescription: Exploration of available careers in psychology with a bachelor’s degree as well as career options for individuals after graduate school (e.g., master’s degree, PhD, PsyD, etc.). All assignments will be aimed at helping students learn more about available opportunities and develop skills needed to find a job and/or get into graduate school. This course is recommended during the sophomore or junior year.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research on available psychology career options
Use of digital job search tools
Creation of application materials for job and graduate school
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Verbal and written communication for job applications

courseDescription: An application of psychological principles and research to human behavior in work settings. Among the topics covered are personnel selection, training, and evaluation; employee motivation and job satisfaction; and organizational leadership and theory.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of employee motivation and job satisfaction
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of organizational leadership and theory

courseDescription: The behavior of the individual as affected by other people and groups. Interpersonal attraction, attitude change, group dynamics, and the application of psychology to social problems are among the topics covered.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating psychology principles to social problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of individuals on group behavior
Applying social psychology principles to real-world issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Applying group dynamics to team leadership
Influencing attitude and behavior change within organizations

courseDescription: This course surveys the evolution and future of clinical psychology, covering research, assessment and intervention, and subspecialities.

Course examines how psychological states (e.g., anxiety, stress) influence physical health. The course also examines how physical states (e.g., illness, pain, injury) influence psychological health. Topics include the impact of stress on health and proneness to illness; coping with illness, injury and trauma; and the role of health-enhancing behaviors in maintaining physical health.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathetic communication with individuals coping with illness, injury or trauma
Ability to convey complex psychological concepts in understandable terms
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of psychological impacts on physical health
Identifying and understanding the influence of stress and anxiety on health
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions about health psychology topics

courseDescription: This course introduces students to the fundamental principles of human-computer interaction. Emphasis is placed on leadership knowledge needed to implement human-centered design practices into an organization's culture.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementing Human-Centered Design in Digital Platforms
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating the Importance of Human-Centered Design
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the Effectiveness of Human-Centered Design
Solving Usability Issues in Digital Platforms
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Incorporating Human-Centered Design in Organizational Culture

courseDescription: This course examines and discusses psychological theories and research that focus on human strengths and potential. Factors that contribute to happiness and a fulfilling life are emphasized. Lectures, self-assessments and experiential exercises are used to understand how to cultivate a meaningful life.

The study of crime from a psychological perspective. Topics include theories of criminal behavior, violent and non-violent crime, sexual offenses, insanity, addiction, white collar crime, and other criminal behaviors.
The application of inferential statistical principles to psychological research problems.

An examination of research principles and techniques in psychology. Experimental design and interpretation is stressed.  Students learn to locate and read technical articles and to report on research projects in the style of the American Psychological Association.  This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Reporting on research projects in APA style

courseDescription: A study of the psychological development of the child with physical, emotional, social, intellectual, and educational disabilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of physical, emotional, social, intellectual, and educational disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with children with varied abilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing effective strategies to support exceptional children

courseDescription: A survey of the processes of development during adolescence. Covers topics such as the influences of biological, emotional, social, and cognitive factors on personality development and adjustment of the adolescent.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Guiding adolescents towards positive personality development

courseDescription: Concepts and theories of sex and gender, including models of how gender roles are developed and maintained, will be examined. Major research findings regarding gender will be reviewed.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of theories and models of gender
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing and maintaining models of gender roles

courseDescription: An examination of the effects of psychoactive drugs on behavior and the factors involved in drug use. Current research literature is discussed.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of research literature
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of drug behavior studies

courseDescription: The application of psychological principles and research to the development and improvement of personnel subsystems in business and industry.  Emphasis is placed on the assessment, selection and training of workers and manager.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of improvement areas in personnel subsystems
Problem-solving in worker and manager selection
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills in assessment and selection processes
Leadership skills in training program development

courseDescription: The application and evaluation of psychological principles and research relating human behavior to the design of tools, technology, and the work environment.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of psychological principles to design
Understanding of technology and tool design
Research relating human behavior to work environment design
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of tool and technology design

courseDescription: This course emphasizes the study of human behavior in organizations. Topics include leadership, motivation, group behavior, communications, power and politics, and organization change.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and proposing solutions for issues related to power and politics

courseDescription: The development of children within their diverse environments is examined. A focus is on the methods used to understand how children experience their world.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of environmental influences on child development

courseTitle: The Psychology of Adulthood and Aging
courseDescription: The study of adults with emphasis on aging. Current theories and research as well as the characteristics, lifestyles, and activities of adulthood and aging will be discussed.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within different age groups
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of behavioral patterns in adults
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of resources for aging adults
Leading discussions on adult and aging lifestyles

courseDescription: A study of critical issues in human sexuality; gender and sexual identity, sexual arousal and erotic behavior, relationship development, and sexual dysfunction and deviation disorders.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of sexual disorders and deviations
Expertise in gender and sexual identity studies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of sexual dysfunction cases
Observation and interpretation of erotic behaviors

courseDescription: This course affords students the opportunity to earn course credit for their work in supporting instructors and engaging with their peers in an undergraduate level course. It is designed for motivated and academically inclined students who wish to contribute to the educational environment and gain valuable, practical experience. Students work with instructors to identify appropriate tasks to be completed. 1-3 credits may be earned based on the number of hours involved in direct activities for the assigned class (3 credits = 9 hours per week; 2 credits = 6 hours per week; 1 credit = 3 hours per week). Students must be selected by the instructor. Positions are not guaranteed. Maximum of 6 credit hours allowed between PSYC 365 and PSYC 366.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with students and instructors

courseDescription: This course affords students the opportunity to earn course credit for their work in supporting instructors and engaging with their peers in an undergraduate level course. It is designed for motivated and academically inclined students who wish to contribute to the educational environment and gain valuable, practical experience. Students work with instructors to identify appropriate tasks to be completed. 1-3 credits may be earned based on the number of hours involved in direct activities for the assigned class (3 credits = 9 hours per week; 2 credits = 6 hours per week; 1 credit = 3 hours per week). Students must be selected by the instructor. Positions are not guaranteed. Maximum of 6 credit hours allowed between PSYC 365 and PSYC 366.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills for managing course credits

courseDescription: For ODU psychology majors only. Students engage in academically relevant work-related activities in non-clinical settings. Available for pass/fail grading only. Students should work with the Instructor to identify their placement in the semester prior to enrollment. A maximum of 6 credits of PSYC 368 and/or PSYC 369 can be counted towards the major in Psychology. Pre- or

For ODU psychology majors only. Students engage in academically relevant work activities in clinical settings. Available for pass/fail grading only. Students should work with the Instructor to identify their placement in the semester prior to enrollment. Instructor approval is required prior to registration. A maximum of 6 credits of PSYC 368 and/or PSYC 369 can be counted towards the major in Psychology.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying psychological theories to real-world situations

courseDescription: Students doing clinical internships at designated clinical placements must also enroll in this course taught by a faculty member. This seminar addresses the special issues in the areas of safety, confidentiality, and professionalism that arise in clinical settings. Students doing general (non-clinical) internships may also enroll in the course with permission of the Instructor. A maximum of 2 credits of PSYC 371 can be counted towards the major in psychology.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of confidentiality protocols in clinical settings
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpersonal skills for diverse clinical environments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Safety issue resolution in clinical environments
Analytical skills for assessing professional issues in clinical settings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills for managing clinical internships
Supervisory skills in a clinical context

courseDescription: The department offers selected topics that may not be offered on a regular basis.
The department offers selected topics that may not be offered on a regular basis.
A survey of the historical development of modern psychology. The major systems and their influences on contemporary American psychology are studied.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching historical and contemporary psychological theories
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debating the influence of historical systems on modern psychology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the historical development of psychology
Critically evaluating the influence of major psychological systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing historical information in a coherent manner
Leading discussions about the history of psychology

courseDescription: A study of psychopathology, covering various behavior disorders, their descriptions, characteristics, and causation. Methods of therapeutic technique are reviewed.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy for individuals with behavior disorders

courseDescription: A study of the structure of personality and the dimensions along which individuals differ. The contributions of major personality theorists and the implications of current research are considered.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and managing individual differences in a team
Applying personality theories to leadership strategies

courseDescription: An investigation of the ways in which people learn and think. Current models of human memory and cognition are considered in relation to the evidence on human thinking capabilities. The role of language in thought and knowledge acquisition is also explored.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of the role of language in thought and knowledge acquisition

courseDescription: An examination of the history, theory and applications of psychological testing.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpretation and explanation of test results
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and solving complex psychological problems

courseDescription: An analysis of the processes by which humans obtain information about the environment through the eyes, ears, and other sensory systems.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting sensory signals in a social context

courseDescription: Course focuses on basic learning principles and processes; classical conditioning, instrumental conditioning, discrimination, attention, appetitive and aversive conditioning.
The course covers advanced statistical methods and computer applications that build on knowledge and skills acquired in PSYC 317.

A wide variety of psychological research and theory relevant to human behavior in different cultures is examined and the impact of culture on human behavior is discussed.  The course examines cross-cultural research conducted by scholars around the world.  In addition to factual knowledge, emphasis is placed on critical thinking and problem solving.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of human behavior in different cultures
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ethical leadership in a multicultural context

courseDescription: An investigation of the biological bases of behavior including mental illness, motivation, learning, memory and language.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of biological bases of behavior
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing information on various aspects of physiological psychology
Leading discussions on mental illnesses and their biological bases

courseDescription: This course examines the issues and perspectives related to the psychological evolution of African Americans in the United States. Particular emphasis is placed on exploring the discipline of psychology from an Afrocentric focus.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of psychological theories and perspectives
Understanding and interpreting psychological concepts from an Afrocentric focus

courseDescription: For ODU psychology majors only.  With psychology faculty supervision, student develops an honors thesis proposal for approval by the Psychology Honors Program committee. See section on Honors Program in Psychology in this Catalog.

For ODU psychology majors only.  With psychology faculty supervision, student conducts the supervised honors research and documents it in a thesis for approval by the Psychology Honors Program committee.  Student also participates in a required seminar to discuss and present the research.  See section on Honors Program in Psychology in this Catalog.
The course may be taken only once.  An individualized course in which the student does library research and writes a paper.
The course may be taken only once.  An individualized course in which the student does library research and writes a paper.

The entrepreneurship is a course designed to help students enhance their personal and professional development through innovation guided by faculty members and professionals. It offers students an opportunity to integrate disciplinary theory and knowledge through developing a nonprofit program, product, business, or other initiative. The real-world experiences that entrepreneurships provide will help students understand how academic knowledge leads to transformations, innovations, and solutions to different types of problems.
The department offers selected topics that may not be offered regularly.  These special topics will appear in the course listing each semester.
The department offers selected topics that may not be offered regularly. These special topics will appear in the course listing each semester.

For ODU psychology majors only.  Student and faculty supervisor develop and approve a contract of required research activities for the semester, such as attending research lab meetings, data collection, coding and/or analysis, library research, etc.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Attending and participating in research lab meetings

courseDescription: For ODU psychology majors only.  Student and faculty supervisor develop and approve a contract of required research activities for the semester, such as attending research lab meetings, data collection, coding and/or analysis, library research, etc.

This course covers topics related to the physical, cognitive, social and emotional aspects of growth, from conception to death.  It focuses on human growth and development, but other organisms are also considered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of human growth and development
Knowledge of physical, cognitive, social and emotional aspects of growth
Comparative analysis of growth in different organisms
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and empathy towards different stages of human development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to guide individuals through different stages of development

courseDescription: The course provides a conceptual basis for the study of abnormal behavior. Students conduct an in-depth review of the literature related to the classification, etiology, and treatment of mental disorders.

Course introduces students to the fundamental principles of human-computer interaction.  Exposes students to basic psychological concepts and shows how they are used to create effective interface designs.  Covers both theoretical and practical aspects of interface design.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of fundamental principles of human-computer interaction
Application of basic psychological concepts in interface designs
Theoretical and practical aspects of interface design
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating the importance of user-friendly designs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying psychological concepts to solve design problems
Evaluating the effectiveness of interface designs

courseDescription: This course covers history of personality theory and assessment and psychometrics, and introduces tools and techniques aimed at understanding individual differences in personality and assessment of major psychopathology.
Students will receive supervised training in an applied setting in the area of clinical or industrial psychology.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Professional interaction in a clinical or industrial setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Practical problem-solving in a clinical or industrial setting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Supervised leadership in a clinical or industrial setting

courseDescription: This course provides opportunities for advanced investigations of selected topics in psychology.  May be taken by students beyond the first year of graduate study who wish to pursue topics not covered by regularly scheduled courses.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and exploration of unexplored topics

courseDescription: Individual project under guidance of a research advisor.  Required for students choosing thesis option.  Limited to a total of 3 hours of credit.
Individual project under guidance of a research advisor.  Required for students choosing thesis option.

This course will cover research design and methodology.  Topics may include experimental, quasi-experimental, single subject and survey research; validity; reliability; confounds; measurement; sampling; inductive inference.  Additionally, this course will cover Responsible Conduct of Research, including completion of CITI course, protection of human subjects, University Human Subjects Committee and IRB, APA Style, paper structure, references, tables, figures, etc., research proposal writing, including searching for sources, writing, oral presentation, data collection and management issues (e.g., Qualtrics, SONA, data cleaning).  Students are required to complete a Research Proposal with Introduction and Methods and Data Analysis Plan and give an oral presentation of research proposal.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Protection of human subjects in research
Compliance with University Human Subjects Committee and IRB

courseDescription: This course examines multidisciplinary research and theories on issues related to individual and organizational well-being and health.  Occupational health psychology (OHP) emphasizes the promotion of wellness and the prevention of injuries and illnesses in the workplace.  Through lectures/presentations, discussions, and research activities, students will learn about OHP theory and practice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of OHP theory and practices
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promotion of wellness in the workplace
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Prevention strategies for injuries and illnesses in the workplace
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Promotion of organizational well-being and health

courseTitle: Analysis of Variance and Experimental Design
courseDescription: Review of the basic descriptive and inferential statistical procedures with a heavy emphasis on fundamental and advanced analysis of variance techniques.  Topics include contrasts, factorial designs, within-subject and mixed designs, and analysis of covariance.  Course materials are covered in the context of classical experimental and quasi-experimental design.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Use of factorial designs in problem solving
Analysis of covariance for problem solving

courseDescription: Course covers correlation with heavy emphasis on regression analysis in the context of the general linear model.  Topics include partial correlations, categorical and continuous interactions, non-linear regression, and multivariate statistics.  Course materials are covered in the context of correlational designs and survey research.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of the general linear model

courseDescription: An investigation of the ways in which people process and retain information, make decisions, and solve problems.  Current models of structures and processes of human memory and cognition are discussed with particular emphasis on neurocognitive evidence of the brain mechanisms involved in cognition.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with cognitive models and processes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to interpret and communicate complex cognitive data
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision making based on cognitive data

courseDescription: This course focuses on contemporary theory and research topics in health psychology.  The course examines psychological and behavioral issues affecting health maintenance, coping with life-threatening illnesses and chronic diseases, and health promotion.  The course uses the biopsychosocial (mind-body) model as an organizing framework, emphasizing the dynamic interactions among biological, social, personality, and behavioral factors jointly in influencing people’s health.  The course is conducted as a seminar.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of contemporary theory in health psychology
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex health psychology theories
Empathy and understanding when dealing with life-threatening illnesses and chronic diseases
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of health psychology research
Analyzing interactions among biological, social, personality, and behavioral factors

courseDescription: Social science data frequently have a hierarchical or multilevel structure as a consequence of sampling designs or repeated measures. The purpose of the course is to introduce students to the basic principles and applications of hierarchical linear modeling in social science research. Topics covered include an introduction to multilevel analyses, random intercept models, random slope models, hypotheses testing, hierarchical models for limited dependent variables, model fitting, three-level models, and repeated-measures applications.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of hierarchical models for limited dependent variables
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and solving problems related to multilevel data

courseDescription: Quasi-experimental methods is a course to teach techniques for research designs not conducive to randomized-control trials.  The philosophy of these techniques, issues of validity, and analyses are discussed.  Comparisons with randomized-control trials as well as means to strengthen quasi-methodologies for better general causal inferences are presented.
A survey of human sensation and perception emphasizing historical contributions, recent theoretical and methodological developments, and empirical findings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of theoretical and methodological developments in sensation and perception
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex concepts in understandable terms
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating historical contributions to the field
Critical analysis of theoretical and methodological developments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on theoretical and methodological developments

courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to the field of program evaluation as well as to give students practical experience conducting a program evaluation.  Students will get experience creating and conducting qualitative and quantitative assessments.  A course goal is to work in small groups to conduct a program evaluation.

This course introduces classical test theory, including definitions and equations for test reliability, standard error of measurement, and related statistics.  Additional topics include scaling, item statistics useful in test constructions, norms commonly used in educational and psychological testing, test validity and exploratory factor analysis.  If time permits, Item Response (IRT) and Generalizability Theory are introduced.
Technical and Digital Skills: Comprehension of standard error of measurement
Understanding educational and psychological testing norms

courseDescription: This course covers the topics of linear structural equation modeling and focuses on estimation, measurement models, confirmatory and hierarchical factor analysis, structural equations, longitudinal models, multisample analyses, and mean structures.

courseTitle: Multivariate Methods for the Social/Behavioral Sciences
courseDescription: The course is focused on methods and techniques for analyzing multivariate data. Emphasis includes both conceptual and computational aspects of the most commonly used analytical tools when experimental units have multiple measures. A goal of the course is to avoid the extremes of "plug n chug" analyses on the one hand and theorems and proofs on the other to provide generalizable working knowledge of multivariate statistics. Featured techniques are MANOVA, MANCOVA, profile analysis, discriminant analysis, canonical correlation, principal components analysis, and exploratory factor analysis.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of principal components analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying generalizable working knowledge of multivariate statistics

courseTitle: Categorical Methods for the Social/Behavioral Sciences
courseDescription: The purpose of this course is to review the linear regression model and move into categorical methods.  Featured methods are inference using proportions and odds ratios, multi-way contingency tables, logistic regression, and loglinear models.  The generalized linear model is also introduced.
Technical and Digital Skills: Inference using proportions and odds ratios
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to interpret multi-way contingency tables

courseDescription: This course discusses the behavior of the human as a member of a group.  Topics include attitude theory and change, interpersonal attraction, group dynamics, and related theory and applied research techniques.

This course provides an overview of organizational behavior and theory.  Topics include leadership, motivation, teams, social processes at work, workplace relationships, organization structure and environments, and organizational development and change.

This course provides an overview of personnel psychology. Topics include reliability and validity, job analysis, performance criteria, performance appraisal, employee recruitment, employee selection, and training and development.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in recruitment and selection processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in employee development and training
Organizational decision-making in recruitment and selection

courseDescription: The application and evaluation of psychological principles and research relating human behavior to the design of tools, technology, and the work environment.  Theory, methods, and application are emphasized.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying psychological theories to real-world problems
Evaluating effectiveness of tool and technology designs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing psychological methods in organizational design

courseDescription: Basic overview and application of anthropometry, biomechanics, functional anatomy, mechanics, and human physiology for the design of industrial tools, equipment, and workstations.

Review of the physical, cognitive, and performance capabilities and limitations of humans as they interact with modern computer systems. Emphasis is placed on the tools, techniques and procedures for the assessment and effective design of computer hardware, software and displays of information.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of computer hardware and software
Proficiency in using different tools and techniques for system assessment
Designing effective computer displays of information
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Working collaboratively in a technology-focused environment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment of physical, cognitive, and performance capabilities of humans
Problem-solving in design and implementation of computer systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and organizing design and assessment processes

courseTitle: Ethics, Professional Standards, and Responsible Conduct
courseDescription: Ethical principles, APA codes, laws, policies and approaches to ethical decision making will be applied to case studies involving dilemmas and issues in several areas of the professional activities of psychologists.  Students will prepare an ethical and/or professional issue paper and a self-reflection on acculturation into professional ethics and standards.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of APA codes
Understanding laws and policies related to professional ethics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Self-reflection on acculturation into professional ethics and standards

courseDescription: Basic overview of the application of anthropometry, biomechanics, ergonomics, cognition and perception within workplace environments.  Particular focus on the analysis and prevention of accidents at work.  Course requires considerable practice in technical writing.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of technical and safety information

courseDescription: Students will investigate the biological underpinnings of behavior and explore what is currently known about their role in movement, emotions, mental illness, sexual behavior, memory, states of consciousness, sensory perception, thought and language, and several neuro-psychiatric disorders.  Through active learning exercises, i.e., class discussion, reports, critiques, oral presentations, and a final research paper or proposal, students will apply and demonstrate their acquired knowledge and critical thinking skills to the biological basis of human behavior.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research in biological basis of human behavior
Knowledge in sensory perception, thought and language
Understanding of sexual behavior, memory and states of consciousness

courseDescription: Empirically-Supported Therapies is designed to foster the integration of clinical science and the practice of psychotherapy. Course objectives include learning how to identify, evaluate, and implement empirically supported interventions for various psychological disorders.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effectiveness of therapeutic interventions

courseTitle: Seminar in Professional Aspects of Industrial/Organizational Psychology
courseDescription: Topics covered include standards of professional behavior of I/O psychologists, the governance of psychology, I/O psychology professional associations, and professional opportunities for I/O psychologists.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of professional associations in I/O psychology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of professional opportunities in I/O psychology
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of the governance of psychology
Planning and management of professional opportunities in I/O psychology

courseDescription: This course will cover research design and methodology.  Topics may include experimental, quasi-experimental, single subject and survey research; validity; reliability; confounds; measurement; sampling; inductive inference.  Additionally, this course will cover Responsible Conduct of Research, including completion of CITI course, protection of human subjects, University Human Subjects Committee and IRB, APA Style, paper structure, references, tables, figures, etc., research proposal writing, including searching for sources, writing, oral presentation, data collection and management issues (e.g., Qualtrics, SONA, data cleaning).  Students are required to complete a Research Proposal with Introduction and Methods and Data Analysis Plan and give an oral presentation of research proposal.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Compliance with University Human Subjects Committee and IRB

courseDescription: Seminar on the pedagogy of teaching as applied to the discipline of psychology.  Topics include syllabus preparation, lecture and discussion methods, assessment and grading, and teaching portfolio development.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods for different learning styles

courseDescription: This course examines multidisciplinary research and theories on issues related to individual and organizational well-being and health.  Occupational health psychology (OHP) emphasizes the promotion of wellness and the prevention of injuries and illnesses in the workplace.  Through lectures/presentations, discussions, and research activities, students will learn about OHP theory and practice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Examining multidisciplinary research on occupational health
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Conducting effective discussions on occupational health issues
Presenting research findings on occupational health
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing issues related to individual and organizational well-being
Preventing injuries and illnesses in the workplace
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading initiatives for prevention of injuries and illnesses

courseTitle: Analysis of Variance and Experimental Design
courseDescription: Review of the basic descriptive and inferential statistical procedures with a heavy emphasis on fundamental and advanced analysis of variance techniques.  Topics include contrasts, factorial designs, within-subject and mixed designs, and analysis of covariance.  Course materials are covered in the context of classical experimental and quasi-experimental design.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of basic descriptive and inferential statistical procedures
Proficiency in advanced analysis of variance techniques
Knowledge of contrasts, factorial designs, within-subject and mixed designs, and analysis of covariance
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to apply statistical procedures to solve problems
Analytical skills to interpret and analyze statistical data
Capability to use analysis of variance in problem-solving
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of classical experimental and quasi-experimental design
Ability to formulate and implement statistical procedures in an organized manner

courseDescription: Course covers correlation with heavy emphasis on regression analysis in the context of the general linear model.  Topics include partial correlations, categorical and continuous interactions, non-linear regression, and multivariate statistics.  Course materials are covered in the context of correlational designs and survey research.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis in the context of the general linear model

courseDescription: An investigation of the ways in which people process and retain information, make decisions, and solve problems.  Current models of structures and processes of human memory and cognition are discussed with particular emphasis on neurocognitive evidence of the brain mechanisms involved in cognition.

The course is designed: (1) to teach students to write article-length scholarly manuscripts in APA format of publishable quality, and (2) to teach students the critical components of grant applications.  By the end of this course, each student will have prepared a manuscript that is ready for submission to a peer-reviewed journal and have completed sections of a federal grant application.
Technical and Digital Skills: Writing scholarly manuscripts in APA format
Understanding and applying the components of federal grant applications
Preparing manuscripts for submission to peer-reviewed journals
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adapting writing style for peer-reviewed journals and grant applications
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing critical components of grants
Structuring and presenting academic arguments in writing
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Navigating the process of grant application and academic submission

courseDescription: This course focuses on contemporary theory and research topics in health psychology.  The course examines psychological and behavioral issues affecting health maintenance, coping with life-threatening illnesses and chronic diseases, and health promotion.  The course uses the biopsychosocial (mind-body) model as an organizing framework, emphasizing the dynamic interactions among biological, social, personality, and behavioral factors jointly in influencing people's health.  The course is conducted as a seminar.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of behavioral factors in health
Understanding of psychological factors in health
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Researching and understanding chronic diseases and life-threatening illnesses

courseDescription: Social science data frequently have a hierarchical or multilevel structure as a consequence of sampling designs or repeated measures. The purpose of the course is to introduce students to the basic principles and applications of hierarchical linear modeling in social science research. Topics covered include an introduction to multilevel analyses, random intercept models, random slope models, hypotheses testing, hierarchical models for limited dependent variables, model fitting, three-level models, and repeated-measures applications.
Technical and Digital Skills: Hierarchical models for limited dependent variables
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Handling hierarchical or multilevel structured data

courseDescription: This course will introduce students to the theory and practice of longitudinal data analysis. It will examine a number of approaches for modeling change (in continuous outcomes) and event occurrence (broadly defined, in categorical or ordinal outcomes), including a careful treatment of the metric of time as well as missing data. Students will learn to develop, implement, interpret, and report research involving longitudinal data analyses. The use of statistical software is also illustrated.
Technical and Digital Skills: Event occurrence modeling in categorical or ordinal outcomes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Reporting research involving longitudinal data analyses

courseDescription: Quasi-experimental methods is a course to teach techniques for research designs not conducive to randomized-control trials.  The philosophy of these techniques, issues of validity, and analyses are discussed.  Comparisons with randomized-control trials as well as means to strengthen quasi-methodologies for better general causal inferences are presented.
A survey of human sensation and perception emphasizing historical contributions, recent theoretical and methodological developments, and empirical findings.

This course is designed to introduce students to the field of program evaluation as well as to give students practical experience conducting a program evaluation.  Students will get experience creating and conducting qualitative and quantitative assessments.  A course goal is to work in small groups to conduct a program evaluation.

This course introduces classical test theory, including definitions and equations for test reliability, standard error of measurement, and related statistics.  Additional topics include scaling, item statistics useful in test construction, norms commonly used in educational and psychological testing, test validity, and exploratory factor analysis.  If time permits, Item Response Theory (IRT) and Generalizability Theory are introduced.
Technical and Digital Skills: Calculating and interpreting standard error of measurement
Understanding item statistics for test construction
Understanding norms used in educational and psychological testing
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the reliability and validity of tests
Solving problems related to test construction

courseDescription: This course covers the topics of linear structural equation modeling and focuses on estimation, measurement models, confirmatory and hierarchical factor analysis, structural equations, longitudinal models, multisample analyses, and mean structures.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking to interpret complex models
Problem-solving for model estimation and measurement
Utilization of factor analysis in problem-solving

courseTitle: Multivariate Methods for the Social/Behavioral Sciences
courseDescription: The course is focused on methods and techniques for analyzing multivariate data. Emphasis includes both conceptual and computational aspects of the most commonly used analytical tools when experimental units have multiple measures. A goal of the course is to avoid the extremes of "plug n chug" analyses on the one hand and theorems and proofs on the other to provide generalizable working knowledge of multivariate statistics. Featured techniques are MANOVA, MANCOVA, profile analysis, discriminant analysis, canonical correlation, principal components analysis, and exploratory factor analysis.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Conceptual understanding of multivariate statistical tools
Generalizable working knowledge of multivariate statistics

courseTitle: Categorical Methods for the Social/Behavioral Sciences
courseDescription: The purpose of this course is to review the linear regression model and move into categorical methods.  Featured methods are inference using proportions and odds ratios, multi-way contingency tables, logistic regression, and loglinear models.  The generalized linear model is also introduced.
Technical and Digital Skills: Inference using proportions and odds ratios
Familiarity with the generalized linear model
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills to infer from proportions and odds ratios
Problem-solving ability to apply different models based on the nature of data
Critical thinking for interpreting results from different models

courseDescription: This course discusses the behavior of the human as a member of a group.  Topics include attitude theory and change, interpersonal attraction, group dynamics, and related theory and applied research techniques.

This course provides an overview of organizational behavior and theory.  Topics include leadership, motivation, teams, social processes at work, workplace relationships, organization structure and environments, and organizational development and change.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and managing social processes at work

courseDescription: This course concerns the study of leadership and its effects on organizational behavior and effectiveness as well as employee well-being and health. Emphasis will be placed on classic and contemporary leadership theory and research.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding classic and contemporary leadership theory

courseDescription: The course focuses on the major concepts, issues, principles, and findings of job attitudes and motivation at the workplace. The student who successfully completes this course should be able to apply knowledge and skills to workplace issues regarding job attitudes and motivation, as well as stimulate ideas for future research projects.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Applying knowledge and skills to workplace issues regarding job attitudes and motivation
Stimulating ideas for future research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying knowledge and skills to resolve workplace issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding major concepts, issues, principles, and findings of job attitudes and motivation

courseDescription: This seminar discusses models and theories of organizational change and interventions that are commonly used to foster organizational development and effectiveness. Students participate in an organizational consulting project to apply lessons learned in the classroom.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in a consulting context

courseDescription: Weekly seminars address professional and ethical issues in the practice of clinical psychology.

This course provides an overview of personnel psychology. Topics include reliability and validity, job analysis, performance criteria, performance appraisal, employee recruitment, employee selection, and training and development.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership skills in employee selection and recruitment
Organizational skills in training and development

courseDescription: This course covers research findings, methodologies, and evaluation designs for the training and development of personnel in organizations.  Specific topics include needs assessment, learning principles and system design.
This course covers the topics of recruitment, job performance, interviews, internet-based testing, and psychological constructs for use in employee selection (e.g., intelligence, personality).
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of psychological constructs like intelligence, personality

courseDescription: This course covers the job analysis and performance appraisal/management (PA/MA). Specific topics include job analysis methods; use of job analysis results for various HR functions; performance assessment/appraisal methods; multi-source feedback; employee reactions to and use of PA/MA information; rater cognitive processes and affect; rater goals, bias, and accuracy; and organizational practical and legal issues surrounding job analysis and PA/PM.
Technical and Digital Skills: Assessment of legal issues related to job analysis and performance appraisal
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating rater goals, bias, and accuracy
Resolving practical and legal issues related to job analysis and PA/PM
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Utilizing job analysis results for HR functions
Leading organizational practical and legal issues resolution

courseDescription: The course is designed to provide individual students with advanced on-the-job professional experience. Internship assignments must be approved by the student's program of study. Direct supervision is given by an experienced professional at the internship setting.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a professional setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying academic knowledge to real-world problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management in a professional setting

courseDescription: The application and evaluation of psychological principles and research relating human behavior to the design of tools, technology, and the work environment.  Theory, methods, and application are emphasized.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration in a work environment design

courseDescription: Basic overview and application of anthropometry, biomechanics, functional anatomy, mechanics, and human physiology for the design of industrial tools, equipment, and workstations.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of biomechanical principles to problem solving

courseTitle: Methods, Measures, Techniques, and Tools in Human Factors
courseDescription: Experiential survey of methods, measures, techniques, and prototyping tools available for human factors investigations in laboratory and field settings.  The design and execution of experimental investigations utilizing the measures and tools are emphasized.
Technical and Digital Skills: Human factors investigations in laboratory and field settings

courseDescription: Review of the physical, cognitive, and performance capabilities and limitations of humans as they interact with modern computer systems.  Emphasis is placed on the tools, techniques and procedures for the assessment and effective design of computer hardware, software and displays of information.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of computer hardware and software
Applying techniques and procedures for system assessment
Utilizing tools for system design and assessment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Cognitive analysis of human interaction with computer systems
Understanding and addressing physical limitations of human-computer interaction

courseTitle: Theories, Models and Simulations in Human Factors
courseDescription: Survey of the historical and philosophical bases for the use of theories, models, and simulations in human factors applications with a critical evaluation of existing theories, mathematical and cognitive models, and simulations in terms of actual and potential contributions to the field.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of theories, models and simulations in human factors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of existing theories, models and simulations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic implementation of models and simulations

courseDescription: Historical survey of human information processing literature, detailed review of recent developments in cognitive psychology, and examination of the purposes, role and scope of cognitive engineering.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of findings in cognitive engineering
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of human information processing literature
Critical evaluation of cognitive psychology theories
Assessment of the purposes, role, and scope of cognitive engineering

courseDescription: This course covers the developmental processes, facilitators, and barriers individuals encounter in their work lives.  It provides a theoretical foundation in the careers literature and introduces contemporary research in the area.  Work-family conflict, mentoring, organizational socialization, and career success are among the topics covered.

courseTitle: Ethics, Professional Standards, and Responsible Conduct
courseDescription: Ethical principles, APA codes, laws, policies and approaches to ethical decision making will be applied to case studies involving dilemmas and issues in several areas of the professional activities of psychologists.  Students will prepare an ethical and/or professional issue paper and a self-reflection on acculturation into professional ethics and standards.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of professional ethics and standards
Familiarity with legal and policy aspects in professional psychology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and application of ethical principles
Reflective thinking for self-acculturation into professional ethics

courseDescription: Basic overview of the application of anthropometry, biomechanics, ergonomics, cognition and perception within workplace environments.  Particular focus on the analysis and prevention of accidents at work.  Course requires considerable practice in technical writing.
Technical and Digital Skills: Cognition and perception application in workplace
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and application of cognition and perception
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and coordinating accident prevention measures

courseDescription: Survey of theories of attention, factors that influence human performance, and human performance assessment in human-machine systems.  Topics include dual-task performance, vigilance, workload, arousal, fatigue, stress, human error, psychophysiology, and neuroergonomics.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and managing factors influencing human performance

courseDescription: Individual project under guidance of a research advisor.
Must be enrolled in psychology doctorate program.

Students will investigate the biological underpinnings of behavior and explore what is currently known about their role in movement, emotions, mental illness, sexual behavior, memory, states of consciousness, sensory perception, thought and language, and several neuro-psychiatric disorders.  Through active learning exercises, i.e., class discussion, reports, critiques, oral presentations, and a final research paper or proposal, students will apply and demonstrate their acquired knowledge and critical thinking skills to the biological basis of human behavior.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of sensory perception and consciousness states
Exploration of biological basis of human behavior
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of emotional and sexual behavior
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Final research paper or proposal preparation

courseDescription: 1-6 credits each semester for variable credit.
Directed research in preparation for the dissertation.

This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
